Problem:
Consider a complex system where the output \\(z(t)\\) is governed by the differential equation \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = Lz\\), and \\(L\\) represents a linear operator. An integral transformation with kernel \\(K(t, s)\\) defined by \\(z_T(t) = \\int_0^t K(t, s) z(s) ds\\) is applied to the system.

If at time \\(t_1\\), another transformation \\(z_M(t) = \\int_0^t M(t, s) z(s) ds\\) (where \\(M(t, s)\\) is another kernel) is introduced as an intervention, will the state \\(z(T)\\) at \\(T > t_1\\) be unaffected by the earlier transformation \\(K(t, s)\\)?
Explanation: The introduction of the second transformation changes the system dynamics again, adding to the effects of the earlier integral transformation \\(K(t, s)\\). The final state \\(z(T)\\) will thus be influenced by both \\(K\\) and \\(M\\), along with the intrinsic dynamics dictated by \\(L\\). The interaction of these kernels can significantly alter the state at time \\(T\\).
